TilE WORLD BANK Bank Staff Working Paper No. 383 April 1980 FERTILITY AND ITS REGULATION IN BANGLADESH Data from two comparable national surveys--taken in 1968-69 and L975-76 --are used to study fertility trends, levels, regulations, and their determining factors. Annual marital fertility rates declined substantially 'between the two surveys, but the total number of children ever born to each married woman did not decline. This is explained in part by the nature of these fertility measures.' The decline in the annual (current) fertility rates, if sustained, lowers the cumulative rate only after a time lag. In bangladesh, the observed dip in the annual fertility rates in 1974-75 represents a recent phenomenon; it perhaps reflects to some degree the effect on fecundity of the 1974-75 famine in Bangladesh. To the extent this is true, the annual fertility rates will revert to the previous roughly constant trend. If, however, this recent dip in annual fertility rates is a part of a sustained trend of decline, the number of children ever born to each married woman will decrease in the future. The analysis shows no evidence of significant differences in fertility among Bangladesh women who differ in such socioeconomic characteristics as educa- tion, exposure to urban influences and occupation. Biological or involuntary factors underlie most of the existing individual differences. These factors explain why bangladesh women -- although attaining the natural fertility rather than a controlled level -- have a much lower level of fertility than what could be considered biologically maximum. Also, the finding that physical factors are significant supports the hypothesis thaLt the 1974-75 dip in annual fertility reflects, to a large extent, the effect of famine conditions. between the two surveys, there have been significant, favorable changes in attitudes toward and knowledge about contraception across all socioeconomic groups. Nonetheless, contraceptive practice increased only slightly, reflecting, perhaps, the existence of a lag between favorable disposition to family planning and its adoption. However, unlike fertility, contraceptive variables are significantly related to socioeconomic development variables such as education, indicating that with socioeconomic development more substantial gains can be expected in contraceptive knowledge, attitudes, and practices in Bangladesh.  SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION Bangladesh, where the vast majority of people live in dire poverty, is seriously overpopulated. Fertility levels and trends, fertility regulation, and the factors determining fertility have great policy significance for Bangladesh, yet little is known about them. Two comparable national surveys, the World Fertility Survey (WFS) for Bangladesh, held in 1975-76, and the Impact of Family Planning Survey, held in 1968-69, can be analyzed. This paper analyzes the two data sets, essentially addressing the following two questions: (1) How do the various socioeconomic groups of Bangladesh women compare on the measures of fertility and of contraceptive knowledge, attitudes, and practices (KAP)--estimated from the two surveys? (2) What factors explain group and individual differences in fertility and KAP measures at the times of the two surveys? Several interesting findings emerged from the analysis. First, the data clearly indicates that the annual marital fertility rates declined substantially between the two surveys. If the entire period spanned by the two surveys is considered, the decline is approximately 32 percent between 1960-62 and 1974-75. Higher declines were observed in the lowest income occupational groups examined--the nonowner cultivators and nonagricultural laborers--and among the most educated and the highest income occupational group--the officials. No major changes among the middle strata--the owner cultivator and the business classes--were discernible.
 Second, unlike the trend in the cross-sectional marital fertility rates, cumulative fertility for each married woman shows no decline as mea- sured by the total number of children ever born--at the times of the national surveys. No significant differences in cumulative fertility between rural and urban areas or across occupational groups are observed. Both in 1969 and 1976, the average number of children ever born per married woman is about 4 for all ages combined. When disaggregated by urban and rural areas, and by various occupational groups, this figure still remains around 4 in all groups. This is consistent with the hypothesis that the level of cumulative fertility among Bangladesh women still conforms to their natural fertility levels. Choice or regulation does not seem to play a significant role in the determi- nants of family size; the family size norm is uniformly high across all socioeconomic strata. Third, the observed discrepancy between the trends in the annual and cumulative fertility for each married woman is partially explained by the way these measures are constructed. If there is a decline in the current fertility rate, its reducing effect on the cumulative fertility rate will be felt only after a time lag. If the 1974-75 dip in the annual fertility rates (compared with those of 1968-69) is only a recent phenomenon, the cumulative fertility rate--measured by children ever born--will not capture the decline. The dip in the annual fertility rates in 1974-75 possibly reflects the effect of the 1974-75 famine on fecundity in Bangladesh. If true, this dip would probably be temporary and annual fertility would revert to its previous roughly constant trend. If the fertility reduction is part of a sustained declining trend, the cumulative fertility measure will show future decreases.
 - iii - Fourth, the multivariate analysis of individual fertility supports the aggregate analysis. Only small differences in fertility exist among individuals who differ in such socioeconomic characteristics as education, exposure to urban influences, and occupation. This is consistent with the finding that a uniform trend of cumulative fertility appears across socio- economic groups. Most Bangladesh women attain natural rather than controlled fertility, regardless of their socioeconomic status. However, the facts that there are some small differences in fertility among the socioeconomic groups and, more importantly, that the overall fertility is significantly lower than what can be considered biologically possible, indicate the effect of biologi- cal or involuntary factors. The total number of children of married women at the end of their reproductive age is, on average, between six and seven in Bangladesh, compared with nine to eleven among the Hutterites of North America. The significant role of biological or involuntary factors is also consistent with the hypothesis that the 1974-75 dip in annual fertility may reflect, to a large extent, the effect of famine. Fifth, between the two surveys, significant, favorable changes have occurred in attitudes toward and knowledge about contraception across all socioeconomic groups. This is probably the effect of the intensive campaign of the official family planning program, which has been operating since 1962. Compared to the level in contraceptive knowledge and attitudes, the increase in the contraceptive practice rate is low. Even use of contraceptives re mained well below 20 percent of all eligible women in most socioeconomic groups, whereas the knowledge about modern contraceptives reached a level of over 60 percent among some groups. Intention to use contraceptives in the future also passed 30 percent among women of some socioeconomic groups. This
 - iv - gap perhaps reflects a lag between favorable disposition to family planning and its adoption. Unlike fertility, contraceptive knowledge, attitudes, and practices are significantly related to socioeconomic variables such as educa- tion, indicating that development probably will have a strong positive effect on these variables. Sixth, this paper identifies a few priority areas for further research. Among the questions that might be asked are the following: (1) Is the 1974-75 decline in the annual fertility rate found in WFS substantiated by more recent fertility data? (2) What time lags are involved between favorable disposition to family planning and effectively practicing it and between effective practice and fertility decline? Are these lags influenced by socioeconomic variables and family planning program activities? If so, how?
 FERTILITY AND ITS REGULATION IN BANGLADESH 1/ INTRODUCTION AND BACKGROUND Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries of the world, has also one of the highest rural Population densities. Approximately 90 percent of the people work in agriculture and about 80 percent of the total cultivable land provides food production. Yet, the country imports a substantive amount of food and the balance between population and resources in the Bangladesh economy is precarious. The situation is further compounded by a 2.8 percent annual growth in population; in 1976, a crude birth rate was estimated at 47 and a crude death rate, at 18. Reduction of population growth rate has, therefore, been the major goal for national planners since the early sixties, and international agencies including the World Bank have strongly supported this goal. (Among the countries where the Bank has a population project, Bangladesh has received the largest International Development Association credit for the population sector.) An official family planning program has been in operation since 1962. In spite of the seriousness of the population issue and the existence of an official family planning program for nearly two decades, recent levels of and trends in fertility and contraceptive practice among Bangladesh women are not known. Although several studies have examined fertility levels, trends, and differentials in fertility as well as in contraceptive knowledge, attitude, and practice in Bangladesh, the emerging picture is unclear. Some of these studies revealed the persistence of high fertility patterns consistent with the noncontracepting nature of the population (Afzal, 1967; Schultz, 1970; Blacker, 1977; Cains and DeVries-Baastiens, 1976; Chowdhury et al., 1970; Sirageldin et al., 1975 ). Some of the findings of the studies are-contradictory. For example, in his examination of retrospective pregnancy histories from central Bangla- desh, Schultz (1970) found that total marital fertility declined in 1950s. However, in analyzing the pregnancy history data of a national probability sample, Sirageldin et al. (1975) found total marital fertility of the early 1960s higher than the 1950 data that Schultz examined. Again, the estimates of Sirageldin et al. of marital fertility in the 1960s were lower than the estimates by Chowdhury et al. (1970) for 1967-69, based on a vital registra- tion system of a localized area of Bangladesh. These studies, therefore, underscore the need to examine the trends of Bangladesh fertility systematical- ly, to determine whether recent fertility actually declined or whether these fertility rates merely reflected random fluctuations or periodic oscillations around a long-run trend. Since little research has focused on the determinants of fertility and contraceptive behavior, knowledge of these subjects is at best sketchy. In a survey article, Arthur and McNicoll (1978) attempt to provide an overview of population and development relationships and issues in Bangladesh, includ- ing a profile of inter-relatedness of fertility and household economic beha- vior. However, the article basically lists hypotheses, rather than providing empirical evidence. The authors seem to conclude that the motivating factors for high fertility in rural Bangladesh lie in the uncertainty and insecurity of rural life in Bangladesh, due in part to the dependence on nature and its variation and also to the prevailing economic relationships in the villages.
 -3- Their thesis is that, given this uncertainty and insecurity and the incentive structure, different socioeconomic groups consciously seek and attain diffe- rent family sizes. Sirageldin states a few themes in several short papers on Bangla- desh, some of which are based on a 1968-69 national survey on the impact of family planning. First, he argues that the evidence of some decline in some socioeconomic groups in Bangladesh can only be explained by changes in environ- mental and biological factors. Second, based on recent preliminary data, he concluded that the share-cropping system in Bangladesh is an important econo- mic motive for some families to have several children. Those families with many working-age male children have grounds to claim land for share cropping. Their claims succeed because the landlords feel more secure that their expecta- tions froum the sharecroppers will be fulfilled if a family has many working children. Amon% the earlier studies, Schultz (1970) traced the fertility trend between 195) and 196U and attributed the broad increase in fertility among 15 to 19 year olds to the improvement in health conditions. Cain (1977) studied the economic utility of children in rural Bangladesh and argues that children represent a reduced economic benefit because they can no longer be easily engaged in production or be employed because of increasing economic deterioration in Bangladesh. Chen et al. (1974) found a positive relationship between birth interval and lactation period and Chowdhury et al. (1976) round a positive relationship between child-death experience and subsequent fertility in a few selected villages of Bangladesh. Chaudhury (1974) also found negative effects of education and labor force participation on total number ot children born. M4any of these studies, however, are based

Moreover, few of these studies used the multivariate framework; as a result, the effect of a particular factor is not always derived by controlling other factors. These studies, thus, did not clearly show the relative roles of various factors that might explain the differential trends in fertility among various socioeconomic groups in Bangladesh. It is also not clear whether family planning knowledge, attitudes, and practices vary along socioeconomic strata or whether they have changed over time. Given this background, the present study essentially addresses two questions: (1) How does the recent fertility as well as current knowledge and attitudes about, and practice of contraception (KAP) among various socioecono- mic groups compare with the earlier measures of the same variables? (2) What factors explain individual differences in fertility and KAP measures at two different times? The availability of two national probability sample surveys, namely, the Impact of Family Planning Survey, taken in 1968-69 but hereafter referred by the completion year (1969), and the 1976 World Fertility Survey (WFS) for Bangladesh, taken in 1975-76 but hereafter referred by the completion year (1976),1/ provide an opportunity to investigate these questions. Although they reflect a difference of only seven years, the data sets can help in analyzing the trend and socioeconomic correlates of fertility and contraceptive knowledge, attitudes, and practices at different times. Data Sources and Methods The National Impact Survey, a nationally representative retrospec- tive survey, contains detailed questions on pregnancy histories, socioeconomic background, marriage history, family planning knowledge, attitude, and prac- tice of the respondents. The sampling frame consisted of all households in Bangladesh. A national probability sample of "ever married" women between the ages of 10 and 50 were selected and stratified by urban and rural residence. 1/ Besides the data for the period in which the surveys were held, the two surveys also provide data for other years on the basis of retrospective answers.
 -5- More detailed information on the Impact Survey is available elsewhere (Pakistan 1974). The World Fertility Survey for Bangladesh (1976) was also a national probability sample of ever married women between the ages 10 and 50. Like the Impact Survey, it also collected information on pregnancy histories, socioeconomic backgrounds, marriage histories, contraceptive knowledge, attitudes, and practices of the respondents. In addition, it collected information on biological factors affecting fertility, such as lactation, postpartum amenorrhea, and age at supplemental feeding. A three-stage sample design was adopted; the first two stages were area selections and the ulti- mate stage was household selection. Once the ultimate sampling unit, the household, was selected, all ever married women between the ages 10 and 50 in each selected household were interviewed. More detailed information about this survey is also available elsewhere (Bangladesh, 1978). In this study, we have utilized only the data on "currently married" women, who numbered 3,088 for the Impact Survey and 5,772 World Fertility Survey. This study focuses on the socioeconomic differentials in fertility and in knowledge, attitudes and practices of contraception, as revealed in the two data sets. Also, changes between the two surveys among different socio- economic groups are investigated. This temporary depressing effect on current fertility of the recent famine conditions has also been reported in an earlier, local study (Chowdhury and Curlin, 1977) as well as in the WFS data set (Bangladesh, 1978) for the entire nation. The recent overall lower fertility levels compared with earlier ones, might have resulted, among other factors, from reduced infant and child mortality. This would lead to prolongated lactation that results in extended amenorrhea, lengthening the intervals between births. The downward trend of infant mortality has been reported in several studies (Stoeckel and Chowdhury 1973, Schultz, 1970, Sirageldin et. al. 1975 b). Part of the reason of the observed difference in trends of annual fertility rates and of the cumulative number of children could be that coverage of live births improved from the 1968-69 survey to the 1975-76 survey as a result of better probing and a more complete recording of past live births in the later survey. Alternatively, there might have been less prenatal loss in recent years and, therefore, more live births compared with the earlier period. The recent progress in malaria control might have removed a particular hazard to the health of child-bearing women and might have contributed to an increase in full-term delivery by pregnant women. Given the nature of the fertility index, the cumulative number of live births does not reflect the extent of the current fertility change that occurred between 1966-68 and 1974-75. The degree of change that the index shows is lessened by including births that occurred before the year for which
 - 17 - the fertility is measured. The effect of dilution obviously would be much less if the fertility had gradually declined for a long time. For example, if the fertility has been declining gradually between 1966-68 and 1974-75, the cumulative index at 1974-75 would show more decline than if fertility had suddenly dropped around 1974-75. In our data the dilution caused by past births was so significant that, with improvement in the recall of births, it showed no drop in fertility. The results, therefore, are persuasive that the lower fertility rates observed in 1974-75 indicated more of a sudden drop than a sustained decline in fertility over time. 1/ If the drop occurred suddenly, it can be assumed that the famine conditions had a consider- able effect on the sudden decline in fertility. CONCLUSION AND IMPLICATIONS FOR POLICY Several inferences can be drawn from the analysis. Unlike fertili- ty, knowledge and attitudes about the practices of contraception are signifi- cantly related to key socioeonomic variables. In 1969 and 1976 ever use of contraception and intention to adopt family planning are positively related to education and to the number of living children. This is true in both the urban and rural areas. Similarly, in both years wives of officials and businessmen who are more exposed to modern sectors or who represent higher socioeconomic strata are more advanced than women from lower socioeconomic groups in knowledge and use of contraception or in intent to adopt family planning. Members of the lower social strata, however, made as much or more rapid progress (measured by percentage increases) than those from the higher social strata in many aspects of contraceptive awareness and practice. This advancement could be caused by the combined effects of the economic pressure of many children and the massive governmental family planning propa- ganda and counseling services. The government's program might have made fertility control available and socially respectable. Thus, people from the lower social strata respond the same as those from the higher social strata to the promotional activities of voluntary family planning program.

 - 45 - However, the economic pressure of many children induces people with lower educational levels to consider contraceptive use or intent to use contraceptives more favorably (tables 16 and 18). To the extent that educa- tion is a proxy for socioeconomic status, economic pressure from high parity makes people of lower socioeconomic strata more favorably disposed towards fertility control than others. Possibly, poorer families want to limit the economic pressure of high fertility, which further aggravates already poor conditions. The negative effect that education or female labor force participa- tion has on the ideal family size (table 21) indicates that exposure to out-of-home influence leads to a favorable attitude toward small family size. However, their effects are not big enough to give rise to any signifi- cant difference in the mean ideal family size among occupational groups (table 13). The expressed ideal family size has not changed significantly between the 1969 and 1976 periods (table 13). The positive effect of the number of living children on the ideal family size (table 21) in both surveys could be explained as a rationalization by a respondent with many children. Some population theorists have speculated on this type of rationalization. Hauser (1967), for example, holds that the response to a question on ideal family size is highly correlated with the actual or completed family size; "the ideal tends to be what has actually occurred." In absolute terms, the proportion of those actually using contracep- tives rather than the proportion of those intending to use them is much tower in the lower than in the higher socioeconomic strata (table 12). Thus, although massive governmental family planning propaganda together with demogra- phic pressure might have created a relatively similar favorable attitude
 - 46 - towards fertility regulation in general, those in the lower socioeconomic groups seem to be slower to actually adopt birth control methods. However, even the lower socioeconomic groups have made fairly rapid progress in this regard during the period studied. The changes in contraceptive knowledge, attitudes, and the practices --discussed in this paper--have implications for population policy and planning in underdeveloped countries. The KAP changes suggest that massive information, about counseling, and services in family planning seem to have a relatively greater effect on KAP at all levels of society than on fertility during the same period. The effect of information and health services on fertility appears to be negligible. The practice of contraception is significantly associated with development indicators such as education or urban contact (tables 14 and 15). However, the actual effect of these development indica- tors on fertility, as the analysis reveals, remains negligible (tables 8, 9, and 10). One explanation for this is that the institutional settings of a high fertility culture are still dominant in Bangladesh across all socioeconomic groups. Part of this dominance results from their traditional family relation- ships that are maintained even when people have more education (Husain, 1956). In addition, urban-developmental changes have not seriously affected traditional family-economic roles or fertility norms. A more plausible explanation is the significant time lag that usually occurs between the increase of contraceptive practice and the begin- ning of a decline in fertility. The seven-year timespan between the two surveys may be too short to show any effect on fertility. Possibly, contracep- tive practice will increase to avoid unwanted births in the short term, but only in the long run will fertility- decline become significant as the family
 - 47 - size norm changes. Given the improvement in living conditions in Bangladesh between the survey years, fertility could have gone up; this probably has been averted by an increase In contraceptive practice. A significant decline in fertility is likely to become evident as the preference for smaller family size becomes more widespread. The results show that some latent demand for contraception exists in Bangladesh. Yet, it is doubtful whether this demand would translate into significant fertility decline in the near future with only the existing voluntary family planning services. However, recent increases in the propor- tion of ever users, in knowledge, and in the intent to use contraceptives between 1969 and 1976--especially among lower socioeconomic strata--is an encouraging trend.

doc.repnme: Fertility and its regulation in Bangladesh
doc.abstracts: Data from two comparable national surveys--taken in 1968-69 and 1975-76--are used to study fertility trends, levels, regulations, and their determining factors. Annual marital fertility rates declined substantially between the two surveys, but the total number of children ever born to each married woman did not decline. This is explained in part by the nature of these fertility measures. The decline in the annual (current) fertility rates, if sustained, lowers the cumulative rate only after a time lag. In Bangladesh, the observed dip in the annual fertility rates in 1974-75 represents a recent phenomenon; it perhaps reflects to some degree the effect on fecundity of the 1974-75 famine in Bangladesh. To the extent this is true, the annual fertility rates will revert to the previous roughly constant trend. If, however, this recent dip in annual fertility rates is a part of a sustained trend of decline, the number of children ever born to each married woman will decrease in the future.
